items.title: ChatGPT Hit with Privacy Complaint Over Defamatory Hallucinations
items.summary:
- OpenAI faces a new privacy complaint in Europe about ChatGPT's false information generation.
- A Norwegian individual was falsely claimed to have been convicted of murdering his children.
- Noyb, a privacy rights group, argues ChatGPT's errors violate GDPR's requirement for accurate personal data.
- The individual has a right to rectification under EU law, but OpenAI provides no means to correct such errors.
- Confirmed GDPR breaches can incur fines of up to 4% of global annual turnover.
- Previous GDPR interventions have led to changes in ChatGPT's operations following similar complaints.

items.title: Michael Seibel is leaving Y Combinator
items.author: Loizos
items.summary:
- Michael Seibel announced he is moving to a “partner emeritus” role at Y Combinator after over 12 years.
- Seibel has been part of YC since his time as a founder, having gone through the program twice.
- He previously served as a group partner, managing director, and CEO of the accelerator.
- The transition follows a previous step back into a less operational role, indicated in a blog post last year.
- His departure may be linked to changes in leadership when Garry Tan became CEO in 2022.
- Seibel plans to take the summer off and then focus on government initiatives.

items.title: ClearGrid, armed with a fresh $10M, is developing AI to improve debt collection in MENA
items.author: Mohammed Al Zaben, Khalid Bin Bader Al Saud, Mohammed Khalili
items.summary:
- ClearGrid, a Dubai-based startup, has raised $10 million to modernize debt collection in emerging markets using AI.
- The company aims to help banks and fintechs recover debts without customer harassment, targeting the outdated practices in the industry.
- Founded in May 2023 by Mohammed Al Zaben and his co-founders, ClearGrid processes borrower accounts via its platform, with 95% of operations fully automated.
- Its AI models can predict repayment likelihood and personalize outreach, significantly improving recovery rates compared to traditional collection agencies.
- ClearGrid claims a 30% increase in recovery rates and a 50% reduction in collection costs for partnered banks and fintechs.
- The startup is currently profitable in the UAE and plans to expand its operations to Saudi Arabia.

items.title: SoftBank to acquire semiconductor designer Ampere in $6.5B all-cash deal
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- SoftBank Group will acquire Ampere Computing for $6.5 billion in cash.
- The acquisition aims to enhance SoftBank's investment in AI infrastructure.
- Ampere will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary, with the deal expected to close in the second half of 2025.
- Major shareholders Carlyle and Oracle will sell their stakes, comprising over 90% of Ampere's ownership.
- Ampere, founded in 2017, employs about 1,000 engineers and specializes in high-performance computing chips based on ARM technology.
- This acquisition follows a series of recent investments by SoftBank in AI-related projects and technologies.

items.title: How a $6M bet on Wiz turned into a massive 200x return for one early backer
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Wiz was acquired by Alphabet for $32 billion, promising large returns for investors.
- Sequoia Capital, an early investor, stands to make $3 billion, around 25x their investment.
- Cyberstarts invested $6.4 million in Wiz's seed round, expecting to make $1.3 billion, a return of 222x.
- Cyberstarts has total returns of $1.42 billion, including earlier share sales.
- Index Ventures, another major backer, will profit over $3.8 billion from the deal.

items.title: OpenAI’s o1-pro is the company’s most expensive AI model yet
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI has launched a more powerful version of its o1 AI model called o1-pro in its developer API.
- The pricing for o1-pro is $150 per million input tokens and $600 per million generated tokens, making it significantly more expensive than previous models.
- Early impressions of o1-pro have been mixed, with issues reported handling certain tasks like Sudoku puzzles.
- Despite slight performance improvements over o1 on coding and math problems, the overall feedback has not been overwhelmingly positive.

items.title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
items.summary:
- Stalkerware apps are designed for spying on partners, with over 25 known hacked companies since 2017.
- The SpyX breach compromised the data of nearly 2 million victims, following previous breaches like Cocospy and mSpy.
- Stalkerware companies often market their products for illegal surveillance, creating significant risks for victims' personal data.

items.title: Data breach at stalkerware SpyX affects close to 2 million, including thousands of Apple users
items.summary:
- A data breach at consumer-grade spyware SpyX affected nearly 2 million people, including many Apple users.
- The breach occurred in June 2024 but was reported only recently, with no communication to affected customers.
- The leaked data included 1.97 million records, most associated with SpyX and its clones MSafely and SpyPhone.
- About 40% of the email addresses were already listed in Have I Been Pwned.
- The breach featured plaintext Apple Account usernames and passwords, raising security concerns for Apple users.
- Google removed a Chrome extension linked to SpyX to uphold store policies against unauthorized surveillance apps.

items.title: X users treating Grok like a fact-checker spark concerns over misinformation
items.summary:
- Users on Elon Musk’s X are seeking fact-checking from Musk’s AI bot Grok, raising misinformation concerns.
- In March 2025, X allowed users to ask Grok questions, initiating experiments with user-generated inquiries, particularly in politically charged contexts.
- Fact-checkers worry that Grok can produce convincing yet potentially incorrect answers, exacerbating misinformation issues observed in prior instances.
- Previous calls by five state secretaries urged Musk to enhance Grok's operations post misinformation incidents during U.S. electoral events.
- Unlike AI, human fact-checkers rely on credible sources and bear accountability, addressing transparency issues that AI lacks.
- Concerns arise regarding Grok's misrepresentation of information and its lack of disclaimers, leading to unverified claims.
- There is skepticism about Grok's training data and quality control measures, impacting how it interprets user posts for valid responses.
- Social media dynamics allow misleading information to spread rapidly, raising awareness of its potential social consequences.
- Research shows AI can have error rates of up to 20%, leading to significant real-world repercussions when incorrect information is propagated.
- The role of human fact-checkers remains vital despite advancements in AI, with efforts to incorporate crowdsourced verification models ongoing.

items.title: Sequoia shutters D.C. office, lets go of policy team
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Sequoia will close its D.C. office and let go of its policy team by the end of March.
- This decision contrasts with other Silicon Valley VC firms like Andreessen Horowitz, which are enhancing their policy teams.
- Sequoia's D.C. office was opened five years ago to assist companies with regulatory challenges.
- The firm claims it is well-positioned to maintain relationships in the U.S. and Europe.
- The closure affects policy fellows and three full-time employees.

items.title: OpenAI research lead Noam Brown thinks AI ‘reasoning’ models could’ve arrived decades ago
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Noam Brown, leading AI reasoning research at OpenAI, believes reasoning AI models could have emerged 20 years earlier with the right approaches.
- Speaking at Nvidia’s GTC conference, Brown highlighted the importance of reasoning in AI, inspired by human thought processes.
- Brown is a key figure behind the o1 model, which employs test-time inference to enhance reasoning capabilities in AI.
- While pre-training remains relevant, AI labs are increasingly focusing on complementing it with test-time inference.
- He noted the growing challenges for academia in scaling experiments due to limited computing resources but emphasized potential collaborations with labs.
- Brown criticized the current state of AI benchmarks, calling for improvements that do not require extensive computing power.

items.title: Nvidia reportedly acquires synthetic data startup Gretel
items.author: Alex Watson, Laszlo Bock, John Myers, Ali Golshan
items.summary:
- Nvidia has acquired Gretel, a synthetic AI training data startup based in San Diego.
- The acquisition terms remain undisclosed; however, it is estimated to be valued in the nine figures, surpassing Gretel's last valuation of $320 million.
- Gretel, which was founded in 2019, employs around 80 people, and its technology will integrate with Nvidia's generative AI services.
- The startup had raised over $67 million in venture capital from prominent investors.
- This acquisition aligns with the trend where major tech companies are utilizing synthetic data for AI model training due to diminishing real-world data sources.

items.title: AWS Generative AI Executive Raj Aggarwal Leaves to Launch New Startup
items.author: Raj Aggarwal
items.summary:
- Raj Aggarwal leaves AWS after nearly three years as GM of generative AI and revenue acceleration.
- He claimed achievements include the launch of large-scale generative AI products that increased pipeline generation by 4.9%.
- Aggarwal plans to start a new company, returning to his entrepreneurial roots, without providing specific details.
- Previously founded Localytics and Demand Sage, both of which raised significant venture funding before exits.

items.title: Group co-led by Fei-Fei Li suggests that AI safety laws should anticipate future risks
items.author: Fei-Fei Li, Jennifer Chayes, Mariano-Florentino Cuéllar
items.summary:
- A California policy group co-led by Fei-Fei Li recommends that AI laws address unseen future risks.
- The report released on March 19, 2025, comes from the Joint California Policy Working Group on Frontier AI Models, organized by Governor Gavin Newsom.
- It advocates for transparency from AI model developers regarding safety tests and data practices.
- The report stresses that AI policy should anticipate future threats, similar to predicting nuclear weapon harm without witnessing its effects.
- A two-pronged strategy of 'trust but verify' is recommended for AI developers to enhance safety accountability.
- The report was positively received across the ideological spectrum of AI safety advocates and policymakers, indicating potential support for future legislation.

items.title: Substack rival Ghost is now connected to the fediverse
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Newsletter platform [Ghost](https://ghost.org/) integrates with the fediverse, enhancing connectivity with the open social web.
- The integration allows Ghost Pro subscribers to share and promote blog posts across federated apps like [Mastodon](https://techcrunch.com/2023/07/24/what-is-mastodon/), [Pixelfed](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/14/decentralized-instagram-alternative-pixelfed-launches-mobile-apps/), and [Threads](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/07/what-is-instagrams-threads-app-all-your-questions-answered/).
- Ghost's social web beta enables users to follow accounts, interact with posts, and utilize a reader for social feeds, with a more finalized integration expected in Ghost 6.0.

items.title: A key DeepMind robotics researcher left Google and Nvidia has already backed his stealth startup
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Pete Florence, a senior researcher at DeepMind, has left Google to establish a robotics startup named [Generalist AI](https://generalistai.com/).
- The startup has received backing from Nvidia, as announced during a panel at the GTC conference.
- Florence aims to develop general-purpose robots, stating a desire to reduce the marginal cost of physical labor to zero.
- Other DeepMind alumni have similarly founded companies in robotics and AI.

items.title: Bluesky made more money selling t-shirts mocking Zuckerberg than custom domains
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber wore a t-shirt mocking Mark Zuckerberg at SXSW, leading to high demand for sales.
- The company made more money in one day of t-shirt sales than in two years of custom domains sales.
- The t-shirts retail for $40 and feature the phrase "Mundus sine Caesaribus" as a rebuttal to Zuckerberg's "Aut Zuck aut nihil".
- Bluesky quickly sold out of the initial t-shirt printing and reopened orders for a week.
- Domain sales were not heavily promoted and not integrated into the Bluesky app, leading to low revenue.

items.title: xAI launches an API for generating images
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, has launched an image generation API called "grok-2-image-1212."
- The model can generate up to 10 images per request, limited to 5 requests per second, at $0.07 per image.
- xAI’s pricing is comparable to partners and competitors, with Black Forest Labs charging around $0.05 per image and Ideogram $0.08.
- The API currently does not allow adjustments to image quality, size, or style, and prompts are subject to revision by a "chat model."
- xAI is reportedly seeking a $10 billion funding round, aiming for a valuation of $75 billion and is expanding its data center in Memphis.

items.title: Telegram founder Pavel Durov says app now has 1B users, calls WhatsApp a ‘cheap, watered down imitation’
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Telegram founder Pavel Durov announced the app has surpassed 1 billion active users, up from 950 million last year.
- Last year, Telegram registered $547 million in profits and became profitable in December 2024.
- Durov criticized WhatsApp, labeling it as a cheap imitation of Telegram, and highlighted Telegram’s independence and growth despite competition.
- Outside of China, WhatsApp leads in chat platforms with over 2 billion monthly active users.
- Both platforms compete to attract businesses and creators with features like business accounts and channels.
- Telegram appeals to crypto enthusiasts by integrating the TON blockchain and enabling decentralized apps for various functionalities.

items.title: Elon Musk’s X reportedly bounces back to $44B valuation
items.summary:
- X's valuation has reportedly bounced back to **$44 billion** according to the **Financial Times**.
- Elon Musk purchased the platform (formerly Twitter) for $44 billion in 2022.
- A separate **Bloomberg** report indicates that X raised close to **$1 billion** in funding, valuing the company at around **$32 billion**.
- Musk himself participated in the equity raise.
- X's valuation dropped as low as **$10 billion** last September according to **Fidelity Investments**.
- Despite a revenue decline since Musk's takeover, X reported **$1.2 billion** in adjusted earnings for 2024.

items.title: Judge orders Citibank to release nonprofit funds, rejects EPA’s arguments
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- A federal judge ruled the EPA acted arbitrarily in terminating contracts with three nonprofits immediately following funding freezes.
- The judge issued a temporary restraining order for the EPA and Citibank to allow access to the funds.
- The nonprofits had significant financial commitments, including Climate United's $392 million and Power Forward's $539 million, which were impacted by the funding freeze.
- The EPA provided vague reasons for contract terminations and failed to follow necessary procedures prior to account freezes.

items.title: In another good sign for fintech, Ribbit Capital is raising a new $500M fund
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Ribbit Capital is raising $500 million for a new fund, Ribbit Capital Y, according to a SEC filing.
- In 2023, the firm raised $800 million for its tenth flagship fund, Ribbit Capital X.
- The firm has invested in major fintech startups like Nubank, Affirm, and Robinhood, as well as crypto companies such as Coinbase and Uniswap.

items.title: GM, Gatik, Torc team up with Nvidia to accelerate self-driving
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Nvidia's GTC conference featured announcements on advancements in autonomous driving technology.
- General Motors expanded its partnership with Nvidia to enhance its factories and self-driving cars using various Nvidia tools.
- Gatik is deploying Nvidia's Drive AGX and using Drive Thor for AI-powered capabilities in its autonomous trucks.
- Torc is collaborating with Nvidia to develop scalable AI compute systems for autonomous vehicles, targeting a commercial launch in 2027.
- Volvo is optimizing its aerodynamics simulations for the EX90 electric vehicle using Nvidia's GPUs but is not collaborating with Nvidia on driving technology.

items.title: Analytics company Dataminr secures $85M to fund growth
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Dataminr raised $85 million in convertible financing and credit, aimed at accelerating growth.
- The company previously raised $475 million in 2021 at a $4.1 billion valuation but faced layoffs of 20% of staff in November 2023.
- The new funding focuses on expanding operations in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia, as well as developing new AI-driven products.
- CEO Ted Bailey highlighted that this round doesn't set a valuation and was led by NightDragon and HSBC.
- Dataminr provides tools for real-time event monitoring and serves over 800 clients, including the U.S. Department of Defense.
- The company faced controversy over its surveillance practices but claims to continuously improve its technology.

items.title: Streamer Plex raises subscription price for the first time in a decade
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Plex announces its first price increase in a decade for its premium subscription service, Plex Pass.
- Monthly subscription will rise from $4.99 to $6.99, and yearly cost from $39.99 to $69.99, effective April 29.
- Lifetime Plex Pass price will increase from $119.99 to $249.99.
- New features include changes to remote playback and the removal of a mobile unlock fee.
- Users assured that personal media data will not be shared or sold, though new policies regarding Plex activity have been introduced.
- Plex cites rising costs of operations as a reason for the price hike and mentions future features like integration with Common Sense Media and new server management tools.

items.title: Google search, Play Store falling foul of Digital Markets Act rules, says EU
items.summary:
- Google Search and Play Store suspected of violating the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- Preliminary findings suggest Google favors its own services over rivals in search results.
- EU investigating Google's restrictions on app developers regarding directing users to better offers outside Play Store.
- Violations of the DMA could lead to fines of up to 10% of Google's global annual turnover.
- Google claims compliance changes may harm consumers and hinder innovation, potentially leading to safety risks.

items.title: EPA was ‘arbitrary and capricious’ when it froze nonprofits’ Citibank accounts, judge finds
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- A federal judge ruled the EPA acted arbitrarily when terminating contracts with three nonprofits, issuing a temporary restraining order.
- The order requires the EPA and Citibank to restore access to frozen accounts linked to the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund.
- The judge found the EPA's claims of waste and fraud were vague and lacked specific evidence, noting the nonprofits faced imminent harm without fund access.
- Plaintiffs have committed substantial funds to renewable projects, now jeopardized by the account freezes.
- The ruling indicates strong likelihood of success in the nonprofits' case against the EPA's actions.

items.title: Researchers say they’ve discovered a new method of ‘scaling up’ AI, but there’s reason to be skeptical
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Researchers explore a new AI scaling law called 'inference-time search' that may improve model performance.
- Inference-time search generates multiple answers in parallel and chooses the best one, claiming to enhance Google's Gemini 1.5 Pro model's performance.
- Experts are skeptical about the method's practicality, stating it may not be effective for general language interactions where clear evaluation isn't possible.

items.title: Tera AI comes out of stealth with $7.8M to provide visual navigation for robots
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Tera AI raises $7.8 million in seed funding to develop zero-shot navigation for robots.
- The company aims to provide affordable, software-based visual navigation that is hardware agnostic.
- CEO Tony Zhang believes this technology can enable robots to operate in various environments without expensive sensors.

items.title: US teachers’ union says hackers stole sensitive personal data on over 500,000 members
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- The Pennsylvania State Education Association (PSEA) reported a data breach affecting over 517,000 members' sensitive personal information.
- The breach, confirmed in a filing with Maine’s attorney general, occurred during a cyberattack in July 2024.
- Stolen data includes government IDs, Social Security numbers, passport numbers, medical information, and financial details like card numbers and PINs.
- PSEA indicated some data elements were not acquired for every individual and took steps to ensure data was deleted post-breach, hinting at a ransomware or data extortion attack.
- There is no guarantee that paying the ransom ensures the deletion of the stolen data, as seen in previous ransomware incidents.

items.title: EU sends Apple first DMA interoperability instructions for apps and connected devices
items.summary:
- The EU has sent Apple preliminary instructions to comply with interoperability provisions in the Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- Apple must enable access to nine iOS connectivity features for third-party devices, improving compatibility.
- Apple argues the DMA's regulations could threaten user privacy and restrict innovation, calling them anti-competitive.

items.title: ‘The Last of Us’ to stream in American Sign Language on Max
items.summary:
- Max announced the HBO series "The Last of Us" will stream in American Sign Language (ASL).
- This is the first time HBO’s content is available in ASL, enhancing accessibility for deaf and hard-of-hearing viewers.
- Season 2 premieres on April 13, 2025, and the first season will be available in ASL starting March 31, 2025.
- ASL versions will feature performances by ‘Coda’ actor Daniel Durant and ASL performer Leila Hanaumi.
- Other titles available in ASL on Max include "Barbie," "Beetlejuice," and "Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire."

items.title: Hugging Face’s new iOS app taps AI to describe what you’re looking at
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Hugging Face launched an iOS app called [HuggingSnap](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/huggingsnap/id6742157364) that uses offline AI to describe camera views in real-time.
- The app employs Hugging Face’s in-house vision model, smolvlm2, to identify objects and explain scenes without sending data to the cloud.
- It requires iOS 18 or later and also works with macOS devices and Apple Vision Pro for broader compatibility.

items.title: The AI leaders bringing the AGI debate down to Earth
items.summary:
- Dario Amodei, CEO of Anthropic, predicts powerful AI could arrive by 2026, claiming it might surpass Nobel Prize winners in intelligence.
- Thomas Wolf, Hugging Face co-founder, questions the feasibility of AGI from current AI models; believes significant breakthroughs require novel questions.
- Demis Hassabis of Google DeepMind suggests AGI may be a decade away, highlighting current AI limitations.
- Kenneth Stanley from Lila Sciences emphasizes the need for creativity in AI development, arguing that current models lack originality and subjective problem-solving capabilities.
- AI leaders advocating for a rigorous evaluation of AGI prospects aim to advance the conversation about achieving genuine artificial general intelligence.

items.title: Hunted Labs lands $3M to find suspicious open source contributors
items.summary:
- Former NSA deputy director George Barnes makes his first investment as a venture capitalist with a $3M seed deal for Hunted Labs.
- Hunted Labs aims to assess the trustworthiness of open source software contributors, addressing security issues highlighted by a 2024 backdoor discovery.
- The startup secured a $1.79M contract with the Space Development Agency and is part of Red Cell's incubator for support and mentorship.

items.title: Mortgage as an employee benefit? Kleiner Perkins leads $23.5M Series A for Multiply Mortgage
Google unveils redesigned $499 Pixel 9a
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google has unveiled the Pixel 9a smartphone, priced at $499.
- The new model features a redesigned appearance without the camera bar.
- It is powered by Google’s Tensor G4 processor, offering over 30 hours of battery life and comes with 8GB RAM and storage options of 128GB or 256GB.
- Available starting in April in four colors: Peony, Iris, Porcelain, and Obsidian.
- The 6.3-inch Actua display is 35% brighter than the previous model and has a 120 Hz adaptive refresh rate.
- The upgraded dual rear camera system includes a 13MP ultrawide and a 48MP main camera with Macro Focus.
- AI-powered photography features include various editing tools and enhanced night modes.
- The Pixel 9a is reportedly more durable with an IP68 rating.

items.title: Zoox recalls software on 258 self-driving cars over unexpected braking
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Zoox issues a voluntary recall for 258 self-driving cars due to hard braking issues in its autonomous driving system.
- The recall follows a preliminary investigation by the NHTSA after reports of motorcyclist collisions with Zoox vehicles.
- Affected vehicles include those with software versions released before November 5, 2024; a software update was implemented by November 7, 2024.
- Recall includes purpose-built robotaxis, which are being tested in San Francisco and Las Vegas.
- The decision comes amid increased regulatory scrutiny following prior safety incidents in the autonomous vehicle industry.

items.title: Cape opens $99/month beta of its privacy-first mobile plan, inks Proton deal, raises $30M
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Cape launches a privacy-focused mobile service at $99/month in open beta.
- Partnership established with Proton, offering additional privacy services.
- Raised $30 million in equity and debt funding to support growth.
- New mobile plan includes unlimited voice, texts, data, and encrypted voicemail without data tracking.
- Cape's founders include former Palantir national security head; targeting users seeking privacy control.
- Protection measures against SIM swapping and SS7 vulnerabilities included in the service.
- General availability of the service expected later in 2025.

items.title: Vote for Your Favorite Speaker at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI is set for June 5 at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley.
- Six finalists for the Audience Choice voting include notable speakers from various AI domains.
- Voting is open until March 21 at 11:59 p.m. PT; you can only vote for one speaker.
- Finalists include: Mahesh Chayel, Cristina Mancini, Yann Stoneman, Hua Wang, Hardik Vasa, and Marcie Vu.
- Attendees are encouraged to purchase tickets to save and secure spots in leading discussions.

items.title: Google now lets kids use Google Wallet for in-store payments in select countries
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announced that kids in the US, UK, Australia, Spain, and Poland can now use Google Wallet for in-store payments.
- Parents must give consent for adding payment cards and will receive transaction notifications via email.
- Kids can also use Google Wallet for items like event tickets and gift cards but not for online purchases.
- The process requires parents to verify their identity in the Wallet app before adding a card for their child.
- This move follows similar features offered by Apple through Apple Cash Family.

items.title: Agentic AI Startup AMT Aims to Be ‘Google Adwords for Influencers,’ Raises Seed Round
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- AMT raised $3.5 million in a seed funding round led by NFX to simplify influencer marketing through AI.
- The AI agent, Lyra, can autonomously communicate with influencers for booking campaigns and managing relationships.
- AMT claims its platform reduces the average time to secure an influencer partnership from nine hours to five minutes.
- The influencer market is projected to be worth $266.92 billion in 2025, highlighting the demand for efficient marketing solutions.

items.title: Researchers name several countries as potential Paragon spyware customers
items.summary:
- Six countries suspected to be customers of Paragon Solutions: Australia, Canada, Cyprus, Denmark, Israel, and Singapore.
- Report published by The Citizen Lab identifies the governments as potential Paragon spyware deployments.
- WhatsApp reported targeting around 90 users with Paragon spyware in January, causing a scandal in Italy.
- Paragon claims to distinguish itself as a responsible spyware vendor compared to NSO Group.
- U.S. venture capital AE Industrial Partners acquired Paragon for at least $500 million in 2024.
- Citizen Lab mapped server infrastructure linked to Paragon's spyware tool named Graphite, identifying customer countries based on digital certificates.
- Paragon's spyware reportedly targets specific apps on devices without needing user interaction, making detection more challenging.

items.title: Shopify transfers its US listing from the NYSE to the Nasdaq
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Shopify is moving its U.S. stock listing from the NYSE to the Nasdaq, effective March 31.
- The removal of its Class A shares from the NYSE is set for March 28, with no change to its Toronto Stock Exchange listing.
- The company recently reported Q4 2024 revenues of $2.8 billion, a 31% increase year-on-year, with a market cap of $121 billion.

items.title: Academics accuse AI startups of co-opting peer review for publicity
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Controversy surrounds AI-generated studies submitted to the ICLR conference, raising ethical questions about peer review.
- Three AI labs (Sakana, Intology, Autoscience) generated studies; Sakana informed ICLR, while Intology and Autoscience did not.
- Academics express concern over the misuse of peer review, arguing it undermines the volunteer efforts of human reviewers.

items.title: Prezent raises $20M to build AI for slide decks
items.author: Rajat Mishra, Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Prezent has raised $20 million to enhance its AI for generating slide decks.
- Founded in 2021 by Rajat Mishra, the Los Altos-based startup targets biopharma and tech industries, serving around 150 Fortune 2000 companies.
- The funding will enable expansion into financial services and manufacturing markets as well as geographical growth in Europe, Japan, and Singapore.

items.title: US paid music subscribers cross 100 million mark for the first time
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- The U.S. reached 100 million paid subscribers for music streaming services in 2024, according to a report by [RIAA](https://www.riaa.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/RIAA-2024Year-End-Revenue-Report.pdf).
- This is an increase from 96.8 million in 2023, reflecting a year-on-year growth of approximately 3%.
- Spotify holds a 36% market share in the U.S., followed by Apple Music at 30.7%.
- Streaming revenue accounted for 84% of total music revenue in 2024, equating to $14.9 billion, with paid subscriptions generating $11.7 billion, a 5% increase from the previous year.
- Pricing increases from streaming services like Spotify, Apple Music, and YouTube may have contributed to the higher revenues.

items.title: Aletiq secures $6.5M for its SaaS tool focused on product lifecycle management
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Aletiq has secured €6 million ($6.5 million) in funding led by Point Nine.
- The startup focuses on developing SaaS-based product lifecycle management (PLM) software for industrial sectors like aerospace and automotive.
- Aletiq aims to provide an intuitive and quickly deployable solution, differentiating itself from existing complex PLM systems.

items.title: Factorial, a HR unicorn, snaps up $120M from General Catalyst to boost sales and marketing
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Factorial, based in Barcelona, raised $120 million from General Catalyst for sales and marketing initiatives.
- The company experienced significant growth, with 13,000 paying businesses and sixfold revenue increase over the past year.
- This funding is a non-dilutive loan from General Catalyst's Customer Value fund, intended to help boost Factorial's go-to-market strategy, not an equity investment.
- The funds come amid legal challenges in the HR sector, specifically involving competitors Deel and Rippling.
- Factorial has previously raised $200 million from General Catalyst under similar non-dilutive terms, indicating strong investor interest in its growth potential.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- In 2025, over 22,000 tech workers have lost their jobs, with 16,084 layoffs occurring in February alone.
- Siemens to lay off approximately 5,600 jobs globally, focusing on automation and electric vehicle segment.
- HelloFresh plans to cut 273 jobs in Texas as part of a site consolidation.
- Notable layoffs include 340 at Wayfair and 2,500 at HPE due to financial adjustments.
- Major companies such as NASA and TikTok also announced job cuts.
